skill.name: omakase-off
skill.description: This skill should be used as the entry gate for build/create/implement requests. Triggers on "build X", "create Y", "implement Z", "add feature", "try both approaches", "not sure which approach". Offers brainstorm-together or omakase (chef's choice parallel exploration) options. Detects indecision during brainstorming to offer parallel exploration.

skill.author: 2389-research

security_audit.summary: Pure prompt-based orchestrator skill with no executable code. Contains only markdown workflow instructions for Claude. No scripts, network operations, filesystem access, or external command execution. Risk level is safe.

content.value_statement: Users often struggle to choose between different architectural approaches. This skill offers parallel exploration of multiple approaches, letting real code and tests determine the best solution.
actual_capabilities: Detects build, create, and implement requests as entry points
Presents brainstorm-together vs omakase parallel exploration options
Generates 2-5 distinct architectural approaches for parallel implementation
Dispatches multiple subagents in parallel to implement each approach
Runs scenario tests against all variants to determine the winner
Detects indecision during brainstorming to offer parallel exploration
limitations: Entry gate only - does not implement code itself
Requires other skills for full execution (scenario-testing, fresh-eyes-review, git-worktrees)
Does not evaluate code quality or security of implementations
Limited to 5-6 variants to avoid combinatorial explosion

use_cases.title: Compare implementation approaches
use_cases.description: Explore different architectural choices (storage, framework, auth) in parallel and let tests decide.

use_cases.title: Break through indecision
use_cases.description: When unsure about technical decisions, implement multiple options and compare real results.

use_cases.title: Validate design choices
use_cases.description: Test competing architectural approaches against the same scenarios before committing.

prompt_templates.title: Build request
prompt_templates.prompt: I want to build a [type of application]. [Brief requirements].

prompt_templates.title: Feature request
prompt_templates.prompt: Add a feature for [capability]. I am not sure whether to use [approach A] or [approach B].

prompt_templates.title: Parallel exploration
prompt_templates.prompt: Let's try both approaches in parallel and see which one works better.

prompt_templates.title: Indecision handling
prompt_templates.prompt: I am flexible on the details. You pick what seems best and continue brainstorming.

output_examples.input: I want to build a CLI todo app.
output: Before we dive into the details, how would you like to approach this?
1. Brainstorm together - Explore requirements and design step by step
2. Omakase (chef's choice) - Generate 3-5 best approaches, implement in parallel, let tests pick winner

best_practices: Let the user choose between brainstorm-together and omakase at entry
Limit variants to 5-6 to avoid combinatorial explosion
Always run scenario tests on all variants before comparison
anti_patterns: Creating too many variants without constraining the scope
Skipping scenario testing and relying on manual verification
Forgetting to cleanup loser worktrees and branches

faq.question: What programming languages and frameworks work with this skill?
faq.answer: The skill is language-agnostic. It works with any language or framework that the sub-skills support.

faq.question: How many parallel approaches can I explore?
faq.answer: The skill limits variants to 5-6 maximum to prevent combinatorial explosion.

faq.question: Does this skill replace my existing workflow?
faq.answer: No. This is an entry gate skill that hands off to other skills for implementation and testing.

faq.question: What data does this skill access?
faq.answer: This is a pure prompt skill with no code execution. It only reads workflow instructions.

faq.question: Why is this called omakase?
faq.answer: Omakase means chef's choice in Japanese. The skill acts as a chef choosing the best approach for you.

faq.question: Can I skip the testing phase?
faq.answer: No. Scenario testing is required to determine the winner objectively based on real code execution.
